sense.name: a supporting prop for holding or displaying things
sense.examples: The assistant set out microphone stands on the stage. The newspapers and magazines were arranged on a stand. The violinist raised the music stand a bit higher. The woman keeps her medicine on the night stand, next to her reading lamp.

sense.name: area for waiting vehicles
sense.examples: I saw John waiting by the taxi stand. We walked over to the buggy stand to ask about prices for a carriage ride in the park.

sense.name: a natural growth of plants, usually trees
sense.examples: Mary admired the stand of old-growth conifers in the meadow. He hid behind a stand of bamboo and watched them leave the house.

sense.name: a booth or stall where merchandise is sold
sense.examples: There were several hot dog stands in the park near the zoo. We enjoyed walking among the stands and stalls of the open-air marketplace. The children rushed over to the ice cream stand and ordered popsicles. She sells her handmade leather bags in a stand at a Parisian market.

sense.name: tiered seating, e.g., bleachers
sense.examples: The fans in the stands were on their feet as the runner rounded third and headed for home. The school is replacing their old bleachers by the track with a new concrete stadium stand. The choir stood on stands, with the tallest singers in the back row.

sense.name: a platform in the open air that a band plays on
sense.examples: In the summer the town band plays on Wednesday evenings on the stand in the park. They built a temporary stand for the rock band at the outdoor concert.

sense.name: a witness box in a courtroom
sense.examples: The witness took the stand and swore to tell the whole truth. His attorney has not said whether the defendant will take the stand tomorrow.

sense.name: an opinion or viewpoint
sense.examples: The senator has not taken a clear stand on the bill as far as we know. What is their stand on the war in Iraq?

sense.name: a cessation or halt
sense.examples: The train drew to a stand by the station. The traffic was at a complete stand for an hour because of the accident.

sense.name: a touring engagement of entertainers
sense.examples: The singer has a one-night stand in Las Vegas next week. The acting troop will perform a three-night stand of Hamlet at the old theater.

sense.name: a defensive effort, usually of a military nature
sense.examples: They learned about General Custer's last stand in American history class. The army made a determined stand at Stalingrad and finally put a halt to the Germans' advance. Sally made a brave stand to defend the project in front of a hostile audience.
